contents.title: Home
contents.description: Remark plugin to parse Markdown Components syntax.

children.value: Remark plugin to parse Markdown Components syntax.
// Use `remark-mdc` plugin to parse mdc syntax
Front-matter is a convention of Markdown-based CMS to provide meta-data to documents, like description or title. Remark MDc uses the YAML syntax with
To define frontmatter, start your document with
section and put your desired data in yaml format within this section.

props.code:
---
title: 'Title of the page'
description: 'meta description of the page'
---

<!-- Content of the page -->

children.value: Inline components are entiries that will stick inside parent paragraph. Like spans, emojis, icons, etc. Inline component can be defined by single
You may want to pass some text into an inline-component, you can do it using
If you want to use an inline component followed by specific characters like
, you can use a dummy props specifier after it.
Note: If you put an inline component alone in a single line it will be transformed to a block component. This is suger syntax for block components.
Block components are components that accept Markdown content or another component as a slot.
Block component can be used without any content.
Or with suger syntax. Note that in suger syntax it is important to put the component alone in a separate line
Block components can accept slots (like vue slots) with different names. The content of these slots can be anything from normal markdown paragraph to a nested block component.
slot renders the top-level content inside the block component.
identifier to render the corresponding content.

props.code:
::hero
Default slot text

#description
This will be rendered inside the `description` slot.

children.value: This will be rendered inside the
MDC supports nested components inside slots by indenting them. In order to make nested components visually distinguishable, you can indend nested components and add more

props.code:
::hero
  :::card
    A nested card

    ::::card
      A super nested card
    ::::
  :::
::

children.value: To create inline spans in your text you can use the
This syntax is usefull in combination of inline props to make text visually different from rest of paragraph. Checkout inline props section to read more about props.

Using the inline props syntax you can pass props and attributes to your components. Also you MDC goes goes a step further and allows you to pass attributes to markdown native elements like images, links, bold texts and etc.
In order to define properties for a component or a markdown element, You need to create props scope
exactly after the component/element definition. Then you can define the properties inline this scope using a
There is also couple of suger syntaxes for common use-cases:

If you want to pass arrays or objects as props to components you can pass them as JSON string and prefix the prop key with a colon to automatically decode the JSON string. Note that in this case you should use single quotes for the value string so you can use double quotes to pass a valid JSON string:
identifier to declare one prop per line, that can be useful for readability.

props.code:
::icon-card
---
icon: IconNuxt
description: Harness the full power of Nuxt and the Nuxt ecosystem.
title: Nuxt Architecture.
---
::

children.value: Harness the full power of Nuxt and the Nuxt ecosystem.
